It‚Äôs worth noting that some content from the original game has been trimmed, resulting in a slightly shorter overall experience, but this streamlining mostly benefits pacing and keeps the narrative tightly focused.

The gameplay is deliberate and rewarding. Driving, while intentionally weighty to reflect the period‚Äôs automotive design, feels satisfying and immersive. Gunplay has been upgraded to feel heavier and more impactful, with each shot reinforcing the tension of confrontations. While the game doesn‚Äôt offer the freedom of modern open-world titles, this linearity is deliberate: it ensures pacing remains tight, mission design purposeful, and narrative momentum uninterrupted. The world of Lost Heaven is densely crafted not sprawling, but every street, building, and ambient detail contributes to the city‚Äôs immersive noir atmosphere.

Storytelling remains the game‚Äôs core strength. Without spoiling any narrative beats, the characters are compelling, voice acting is top-notch, and cinematic direction elevates each scene. The missions are structured to complement the story perfectly, with a rhythm that balances action, tension, and quiet moments for reflection.

Visually, the remake shines. Lighting, textures, and environmental details all work in harmony to recreate the 1930s atmosphere with remarkable fidelity. Minor technical hiccups, such as occasional frame drops or slightly rigid NPC animations, are present but rarely detract from the experience. The sound design is exceptional: orchestral scoring, environmental audio, and weapon effects all enhance immersion, reinforcing the period‚Äôs tone and mood.

Mafia: Definitive Edition exemplifies how a remake should be done: respectful, immersive, and emotionally engaging. While slightly shorter than the original, it maintains the essence of the story and gameplay, delivering a tightly-paced, memorable experience. A must-play for fans of narrative-driven crime games, it balances nostalgia with modern polish, creating one of the most cinematic gaming experiences in recent years.

Mafia is one of the best examples of a game whose true potential reveals itself only once you start playing. I'm convinced that every gamer, no matter their experience, has at least heard of this - and I won't hesitate to say it - brilliant series.

Circumstances were such that I never played the original, and only years later I finally decided to give the remake a chance - the version meant to recreate that same atmosphere and spirit in a modern shell. And I don't regret a minute spent on it.

The story is relatively short, but words can't fully describe how atmospheric and powerful it feels. Mafia becomes so emotional and immersive that only after finishing it do you truly understand why people hold it in such high regard. I would recommend it to absolutely anyone, if only for the incredible story that was once written and brought to life with such skill.

Of course, the story is one thing - certain gameplay mechanics are another. I won't talk much about the driving, since it's extremely subjective and no one can really judge how cars from the 1930s "should" feel. But the shooting? That's worth mentioning.

Gunfights are a core part of the experience, and if you play on Classic mode, you'll quickly start wondering why three pistol shots feel like you're throwing peas at the enemy. There's almost no impact to the bullets. An enemy can tank three shots and keep sprinting toward you like nothing happened - which gets VERY frustrating in the middle of the game when dozens of them rush you at once.

But even with that, you can look past the flaws. The heart of the game is simply too good. And one more important thing - Mafia should never be compared to GTA, because these two games aim for completely different experiences.

Hangar 13 rebuilt the entire experience from the ground up, aiming to preserve the soul of the original while delivering cinematic visuals, enhanced gameplay, and deeper emotional impact.

The result is a stylish and atmospheric return to Lost Heaven, but one that occasionally stumbles under the weight of technical issues and inconsistent AI.

üé¨ Story ‚Äì The Rise and Fall of Tommy Angelo

At its heart, Mafia remains a character-driven crime drama. You follow taxi driver Tommy Angelo as he‚Äôs pulled into the criminal underworld of Lost Heaven ‚Äî a tale of loyalty, betrayal, and survival.

The remake amplifies every emotional beat:

Cutscenes are beautifully re-animated.

Characters have more depth and nuance.

Dialogues feel sharper and more grounded.

While the plot doesn‚Äôt stray far from mafia-genre conventions, it‚Äôs engaging from start to finish. The pacing becomes stronger in the later chapters, delivering a memorable and dramatic conclusion that honors the original game.

üî´ Gunplay ‚Äì Old-School Action with a Modern Shine

Combat in Mafia: Definitive Edition strikes a balance between classic and modern. Weapons feel weighty and powerful, and every encounter is tightly scripted to maintain tension.

The gunplay isn‚Äôt groundbreaking, but it is fun:

Satisfying recoil

Clear feedback

Punchy sound design

However, shooting from vehicles is more limited than it could be. The aiming system tends to lock onto targets rather than offering full freedom, making drive-by combat less dynamic. Still, overall gunplay fits the gritty tone of the world.

üöó Driving ‚Äì Heavy, Dangerous, and Atmospheric

Driving is one of the standout aspects of the remake. Cars feel like authentic 1930s machines ‚Äî heavy, loud, and sometimes unpredictable. They slide on sharp turns, shake on rough streets, and punish reckless speeding.

This gives the gameplay a grounded, dangerous edge. High-speed chases feel intense, and even basic cruising through the city carries a sense of immersion.

That said, the handling can feel a bit stiff at times. It‚Äôs realistic, but not always smooth.

üë• NPCs and Police ‚Äì Immersive but Inconsistent

NPC behavior is a mixed bag.
Sometimes enemies use cover intelligently and provide a solid challenge. Other times they run into your bullets or stand still in the open.

The police system is more interesting:

Officers respond to speeding, crashes, and violence

Chase intensity escalates logically

Escaping the law can be thrilling

However, it‚Äôs also flawed. Witnesses seem to report crimes instantly, and police can be either too easy or oddly unpredictable. Despite this inconsistency, the police system adds tension and charm to the world ‚Äî and is often one of the more entertaining mechanics.

üé® Graphics ‚Äì A Beautiful Tribute to a Classic

Visually, Mafia: Definitive Edition shines.
Lost Heaven is fully reimagined with stunning lighting, detailed environments, and expressive characters.

The highlight is the atmosphere:

Rain-soaked streets reflect neon lights

Fog-covered docks ooze noir identity

Interiors feel handcrafted and cinematic

The game looks so good that your original 4/5 graphics rating is completely justified.

üêû Technical Issues ‚Äì The Remake‚Äôs Biggest Weakness

Unfortunately, the game suffers from frequent issues:

NPCs getting stuck

Missions failing to trigger

Cars behaving oddly or clipping

Graphical glitches

Occasional crashes

These bugs don‚Äôt break the game entirely, but they can disrupt immersion and force restarts. For a narrative-focused remake, these problems stand out.

üèÅ Conclusion ‚Äì A Stylish Return with Noticeable Flaws

Mafia: Definitive Edition succeeds in many ways:
+ Strong narrative and cinematic presentation
+ Excellent atmosphere and visual design
+ Weighty, engaging driving mechanics
+ Authentic worldbuilding and period detail

But it‚Äôs held back by:
‚Äì Frequent bugs
‚Äì Inconsistent NPC and police AI
‚Äì Some limitations in combat and vehicle shooting

Your personal rating of 3/5 is a fair reflection. This is a game filled with memorable moments and emotional storytelling, but it struggles to reach true greatness due to technical shortcomings.

A Remake of Mafia 1 from 2002, it shines itself in Classy Gangster Story set between the Prohibition Era and the year prior to WW2. The Remake plays a lot more like Mafia 3, and while not being as ambiguous as that game was, it shines it in straight forward mission, time of of gameplay and setting which they have nailed.
Starting in the late 1920's you'll experience a series of events between a gang which attempts to assert themself over the fictional city of Lost Heaven, between a man who has to balance between his family and the criminal life.

The game reflects a lot on morality, while lacking in choice it gives a very good story that you can play on with just within a few days on and off. Time is reflected in the game well with its setting, the longer you play the more the cars change to represent the time for example.

However that's not to say there is just good things with the remake of Mafia 1. Cutscenes sometimes do not play Audio which can the immersion a lot before it returns when you start playing. The game is overall blurry, as most modern games has become due to the heavy usage of upscaling technologies. Not only that but during cutscenes, the game uses an extreme amount of resources to play the cutscenes even if they are paused, which should signify a leak.
The intro before starting the game is unskippable, and so is the nearly 15 min long credits list at the end of the game, so that can be a drag to have to play through if you are going to open and close the game often. Movement can also feel a bit sluggish, but it was designed in such a way to make it more natural between the mechanics in the game

But overall it is a very solid good game for both newcomers and returning fans of the franchise.

negative.review:
I really enjoy the Mafia series. The world building and environments Hangar 13 creates are some of the best parts of these games, especially since you rarely get to see settings like these in other titles. This remake does a great job capturing the late 20s and 30s, along with the brief time it spends in the 50s. The series means a lot to me. That said, Mafia Definitive Edition somehow made me want to play Mafia 3 instead of continuing with it, which is something I never thought would happen considering Mafia 3 is mostly remembered for the clip of the mom yelling at the kid to go to the bathroom.

This game frustrates me as a player. I enjoyed parts of it, but I cannot call it a good game without hesitation. It improves on Mafia 3 in some areas and falls behind in others. Mafia 3 is a full open world game while this one technically has an open world but gives you nothing to do in it outside of the story missions. There are no side missions, no activities, nothing to progress outside the main path. Areas are locked behind story beats along with collectibles. If you miss a collectible during a mission you need to replay the story just to grab it. It drives me crazy because the world itself is incredible, but the game does not make use of it. There is so much potential and it just feels wasted.

The gunplay can be great when it decides to function. While driving you can aim your gun, but there is no option to turn off the reticle. It is not awful by itself, except when a police car pulls up beside you and the reticle starts drifting around. When shooting at cars you can wait for the reticle to tighten for better accuracy, but it takes so long that it is easier to just spam the fire button and reload. I would not even bother with the careful shooting mechanic unless the game gave you infinite ammo. Running away is often more effective than actually fighting.

When the shooting works, the game feels fantastic. Sadly there are invisible walls around many objects enemies hide behind. The cover system is decent but not very intuitive, and the controls can feel awkward. The game expects you to rely on cover constantly. On medium difficulty, if you get hit you must take cover right away or you will drop instantly. Running and gunning is almost never allowed. You only regenerate a tiny sliver of health, enough to survive a single hit. I am not asking for the game to let you sprint through firefights with no consequences, but the cover system becomes dull when the game forces you to rely on it every moment. It feels like a version of Gears of War without any of the style or excitement that makes Gears fun. The one thing I can praise without hesitation is the shotgun. It was my favorite weapon in Mafia 3 and it is just as satisfying here.

The PC port is rough. It honestly feels like it needed more time in development. All of the cinematics are locked to something above 30 frames but definitely not 60. There is constant pop in that causes lag and ruins the beauty of the city. I often stop to appreciate how incredible the game looks at night only to get distracted by objects and lights popping into existence. Visual fidelity also suffers. I am playing on high settings and reflections sometimes look unfinished, with white specks appearing instead of proper lighting.

The controls are another problem. On PC the sensitivity slider is awful. There is no separate slider for the menus, so lowering your in game sensitivity makes the menus painful to use. The default is 5, and I had to drop it to 0.6, but that made navigating menus feel like that image of Syphilis pushing the boulder up a hill. To make it worse the game has mouse acceleration on by default, so the mouse always feels slippery. I switched to a controller because of this, even though the gunplay would be better with a mouse.

Controller controls are not great either. It feels like the game intentionally remapped every standard button just to be different. Everyone knows Y or Triangle is used to enter vehicles, it is X or Square. Everyone knows X or Square is used to melee, it is B or Circle. Jump is Y or Triangle instead of A or X. None of it feels natural. There are plenty of unused dpad buttons while the back button is mapped to the car speed limiter for some reason.

The game also freezes at random times, and you can die instantly if you run near a sloped surface or anything that is not perfectly flat. I wish I could recommend the game without hesitation, but in its current condition I cannot. If you are a fan of the series and never played the first game because of how rough the original PC version was, I would suggest waiting for a sale. At around nine hours, it is not worth full price in this state.

update 2:
finished the game, and feeling very underwhelmed compared to when i played mafia 2 a decade ago

the story didn't grab me, i did not find the characters particularly compelling, and overall it felt as if large swathes of the content was missing

there was zero emotional impact that i felt during the narrative's climax, and the reason why is because it was undeserved... the main trio is supposed to come across as best friends, brothers even, but where is that development happening? the plot skipped around so much, running to get to the next action scene, that i never saw these characters live like real people

the protagonist's family is barely shown, we rarely get to see the cast goofing off or doing low stakes jobs, i don't even recall the characters emotionally opening up to each other until the 2nd last chapter

this problem extends to other areas as well; thematically, how can i suspend my disbelief that this is about the mafia when the majority of levels play like a GTA mission? there is no discretion and the violence is on display for half the city to see

where is the hiding of bodies, covering up crimes, staying off the police's radar, etc? how do these losers not get arrested when there is a literal mountain of evidence left behind after each mission? silencing one witness by starting a massive gang battle that ends with dozens of cops dead would not get you off scot-free in any reality

not to mention that the gameplay loop gets stale pretty fast anyways; drive here, shoot a couple dozen enemies, oh no the cops showed up, drive away to lose the heat, now drive some more to get back to base!! the only time this gets broken up is with the odd stealth segment, which of course is rarely done well in action games, and this is no exception

the gameplay systems are also shallow... i recall that in mafia 2, a game released a decade before this remake, if the cops were onto you, they would register your car and license plate, which needed to be ditched or changed at a body shop to become inconspicuous

however, none of that applies here, because the police have the memory of a goldfish; drive two blocks away and it's like the crime never happened! that's far from the only aspect of gameplay that was downgraded between these releases, and a similar comparison can be drawn with character customization (ie clothing options), free roam opportunities between missions (such as robbing stores), etc, the list goes on and on

there are a number of technical issues that impact enjoyment as well, such as full screen / borderless bugs, the game freezing whenever the controller disconnects, cars often getting stuck into positions that prevent further movement, inconsistent rules when it comes to hitting stationary objects while driving, cover that can't be taken on certain objects, or just bugged out entirely, unable to shoot at enemies because the game thinks you're looking at a wall

overall, i did not have much fun playing this game, i would not recommend it to a friend, and i do not understand how this rated so highly with how barebones of an experience it is

instead, i recommend to play mafia 2, which i think executes the ideas in this game at a higher calibre and to greater player satisfaction

I really enjoy the Mafia series. The world building and environments Hangar 13 creates are some of the best parts of these games, especially since you rarely get to see settings like these in other titles. This remake does a great job capturing the late 20s and 30s, along with the brief time it spends in the 50s. The series means a lot to me. That said, Mafia Definitive Edition somehow made me want to play Mafia 3 instead of continuing with it, which is something I never thought would happen considering Mafia 3 is mostly remembered for the clip of the mom yelling at the kid to go to the bathroom.

This game frustrates me as a player. I enjoyed parts of it, but I cannot call it a good game without hesitation. It improves on Mafia 3 in some areas and falls behind in others. Mafia 3 is a full open world game while this one technically has an open world but gives you nothing to do in it outside of the story missions. There are no side missions, no activities, nothing to progress outside the main path. Areas are locked behind story beats along with collectibles. If you miss a collectible during a mission you need to replay the story just to grab it. It drives me crazy because the world itself is incredible, but the game does not make use of it. There is so much potential and it just feels wasted.

The gunplay can be great when it decides to function. While driving you can aim your gun, but there is no option to turn off the reticle. It is not awful by itself, except when a police car pulls up beside you and the reticle starts drifting around. When shooting at cars you can wait for the reticle to tighten for better accuracy, but it takes so long that it is easier to just spam the fire button and reload. I would not even bother with the careful shooting mechanic unless the game gave you infinite ammo. Running away is often more effective than actually fighting.

When the shooting works, the game feels fantastic. Sadly there are invisible walls around many objects enemies hide behind. The cover system is decent but not very intuitive, and the controls can feel awkward. The game expects you to rely on cover constantly. On medium difficulty, if you get hit you must take cover right away or you will drop instantly. Running and gunning is almost never allowed. You only regenerate a tiny sliver of health, enough to survive a single hit. I am not asking for the game to let you sprint through firefights with no consequences, but the cover system becomes dull when the game forces you to rely on it every moment. It feels like a version of Gears of War without any of the style or excitement that makes Gears fun. The one thing I can praise without hesitation is the shotgun. It was my favorite weapon in Mafia 3 and it is just as satisfying here.

The PC port is rough. It honestly feels like it needed more time in development. All of the cinematics are locked to something above 30 frames but definitely not 60. There is constant pop in that causes lag and ruins the beauty of the city. I often stop to appreciate how incredible the game looks at night only to get distracted by objects and lights popping into existence. Visual fidelity also suffers. I am playing on high settings and reflections sometimes look unfinished, with white specks appearing instead of proper lighting.

The controls are another problem. On PC the sensitivity slider is awful. There is no separate slider for the menus, so lowering your in game sensitivity makes the menus painful to use. The default is 5, and I had to drop it to 0.6, but that made navigating menus feel like that image of Syphilis pushing the boulder up a hill. To make it worse the game has mouse acceleration on by default, so the mouse always feels slippery. I switched to a controller because of this, even though the gunplay would be better with a mouse.

Controller controls are not great either. It feels like the game intentionally remapped every standard button just to be different. Everyone knows Y or Triangle is used to enter vehicles, it is X or Square. Everyone knows X or Square is used to melee, it is B or Circle. Jump is Y or Triangle instead of A or X. None of it feels natural. There are plenty of unused dpad buttons while the back button is mapped to the car speed limiter for some reason.

The game also freezes at random times, and you can die instantly if you run near a sloped surface or anything that is not perfectly flat. I wish I could recommend the game without hesitation, but in its current condition I cannot. If you are a fan of the series and never played the first game because of how rough the original PC version was, I would suggest waiting for a sale. At around nine hours, it is not worth full price in this state.

update 2:
finished the game, and feeling very underwhelmed compared to when i played mafia 2 a decade ago

the story didn't grab me, i did not find the characters particularly compelling, and overall it felt as if large swathes of the content was missing

there was zero emotional impact that i felt during the narrative's climax, and the reason why is because it was undeserved... the main trio is supposed to come across as best friends, brothers even, but where is that development happening? the plot skipped around so much, running to get to the next action scene, that i never saw these characters live like real people

the protagonist's family is barely shown, we rarely get to see the cast goofing off or doing low stakes jobs, i don't even recall the characters emotionally opening up to each other until the 2nd last chapter

this problem extends to other areas as well; thematically, how can i suspend my disbelief that this is about the mafia when the majority of levels play like a GTA mission? there is no discretion and the violence is on display for half the city to see

where is the hiding of bodies, covering up crimes, staying off the police's radar, etc? how do these losers not get arrested when there is a literal mountain of evidence left behind after each mission? silencing one witness by starting a massive gang battle that ends with dozens of cops dead would not get you off scot-free in any reality

not to mention that the gameplay loop gets stale pretty fast anyways; drive here, shoot a couple dozen enemies, oh no the cops showed up, drive away to lose the heat, now drive some more to get back to base!! the only time this gets broken up is with the odd stealth segment, which of course is rarely done well in action games, and this is no exception

the gameplay systems are also shallow... i recall that in mafia 2, a game released a decade before this remake, if the cops were onto you, they would register your car and license plate, which needed to be ditched or changed at a body shop to become inconspicuous

however, none of that applies here, because the police have the memory of a goldfish; drive two blocks away and it's like the crime never happened! that's far from the only aspect of gameplay that was downgraded between these releases, and a similar comparison can be drawn with character customization (ie clothing options), free roam opportunities between missions (such as robbing stores), etc, the list goes on and on

there are a number of technical issues that impact enjoyment as well, such as full screen / borderless bugs, the game freezing whenever the controller disconnects, cars often getting stuck into positions that prevent further movement, inconsistent rules when it comes to hitting stationary objects while driving, cover that can't be taken on certain objects, or just bugged out entirely, unable to shoot at enemies because the game thinks you're looking at a wall

overall, i did not have much fun playing this game, i would not recommend it to a friend, and i do not understand how this rated so highly with how barebones of an experience it is

instead, i recommend to play mafia 2, which i think executes the ideas in this game at a higher calibre and to greater player satisfaction

Game just wraps up one mission and throws you into the next.
